reviewText:
In God Mode you play as a descendant of an ancient Greek god who is forced to battle hordes of creatures brought forth by Hades. There are five maps in which you can test your skills, each is vastly different and beautifully designed.

For every area you enter you will be given a trial to complete. You will be unable to enter the next level of the map until you have completed the trail at hand. These trails vary greatly and range from things designed to make gameplay more challenging such as lowering your maximum health, to more amusing things such as making all of your enemies wear silly tophats.

Combat is fun and faced paced as you will continuously find yourself surrounded by enemies. There is a wide variety of weapons which you can earn and upgrade as well as different abilities which you can choose from.

In order to make the game more challenging you are able to choose between different levels of difficulty. There are also different handicaps called Oaths which you can turn on at the beginning of a map to give yourself more of a challenge and earn more gold/XP.

Some of the reviews for this game seem to be taking it a little too seriously. If you buy this expecting a well polished top notch shooter you will be sorely disappointed. I got this game on sale for $2.00 and feel this was a great price for the how much entertainment it has provided. Well worth the purchase if you’re in the mood for some mindless fun, have a fondness for Greek architecture/♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ized mythology, and have a friend or two to play with.

reviewText: God Mode is an online, third-person shooter that focuses on horde mode style game play. The object is to find three other players, and work through five arenas mowing down enemies, and collecting XP.The XP system is pretty standard, although it takes a massive amount of points to level up.The action itself consists of taking on room after room of enemies. The basics of the gameplay are fun yet challenging, but once I tried to go it alone, things started to feel pretty overwhelming. Because the difficulty seems much more approachable with a group of four players, I suggest you stick to co-op. If you're looking for a good story, look somewhere else. The most you get out of God Mode lies in the loading screens that reveal your Olympian ancestry and in the narrator's bemused commentary on your invariably unheroic demise. For its low price, God Mode offers a lot, and has more polish than some bigger-budget titles. There’s plenty to do in terms of character customization, and the gameplay is fun and fast-paced. The Tests of Faith and Oaths add some variety to gameplay, but there’s a good chance you’ll find yourself getting bored once you’ve played through all five maps multiple times. The gameplay and AI just don’t offer enough variety to keep things fresh for longer than a few hours. Still, the basics are solid, and there’s a lot to enjoy about the overall package. If you’re after an arcade shooter that offers a few hours of entertainment, then you could do a whole lot worse than this.\n\n

reviewText:
Overview
God Mode is an area-based 3rd person shooter that focuses on surviving waves of enemies sent by Hades. The player takes control of a God who has been turned into a mortal by Hades and sent into the Underworld. The goal of the game is to navigate the levels, killing hoards of enemies, all while using an arsenal of various modern and futuristic weaponry at your disposal. The game can be played solo or up to four person co-op. There is no voice chat, or even text chat in game, which makes co-op extremely difficult without an external source of communication.

The game has no real story aside from what is mentioned above. Your backstory isn't explained and who the people are that you can select from, don't have a background, nor much information to go by. Your job is to kill or be killed; that's about all there is, really. The characters aren't terribly interesting and, honestly, I found them rather unappealing for the most part. There is a limited amount of customization given: clothing & face. Aside from that, you're out of luck.

The guns themselves are a little more interesting than the characters. As you level up your character, you're given the chance to buy weapons and upgrades with gold, which is earned at the end of the each level in the form of a gold arena. In these arenas, friendly fire is on (which is normally off) and you can either work together, or turn to greed. You get a limited amount of XP for killing teammates, but the experience isn't worth it in the end. You're far better off working together than going in as a Free-For-All (FFA). The amount of gold that spawns is proportionate to the amount of players; more players means more gold.

The levels themselves are interesting, but very, very limited in supply. There's only a small handful (about 5-6) in total, which makes the game very repetitive over long playthroughs or for achievement grinding. While the levels are rather dynamic and visually appealing, they grow weary after several hours of playing.

Aside from the poor quantity of levels, the co-op is hindered by a lack of communication abilities and the inadvertent drops and poor ability to connect to play together. I had no issues with co-op during LAN setups, but playing multiplayer can be a bit stubborn. That, and it is all but dead at this point. You really have to plan to play with others, as the lobbies are completely desolate.

While the game has a lot of problems, it is a nice way to turn off your brain and pass the time. The enemy types are interesting, the level designs are done nicely and the random perks generated during segments make the game unpredictable; each stage has a totem that summons conditions such as stronger enemies, weaker ones, health degeneration, limited drops to even one-hit-kill and enemies with top hats. It's a nice add-on that gives the game a bit of breathing room and wavers off the stench of becoming too stale too soon. While I enjoyed it, the game needs work.


Pros
Ability Totems - My favorite part of the game. It keeps you guessing.
Level Design - There's very few levels, but the ones that the game does have are well constructed.
Co-op/Multiplayer - The game is far more fun with friends.
Gold Arena - Call a truce, shoot your friend anyway. What's not to like? Just don't lose your friend! xD
Hades - He's weird, snarky and makes questionable judgement about your player. I just wish he had more dialogue.
Cons
Communication - No text/voice chat. You better have an external way to communicate.
Lack of levels - Before you know it, you've played all the levels.
Bosses(?) - There are a few and they range from extremely easy to difficult. The progression of bosses is a bit unbalanced.
Achievements - They are extremely grind heavy for you 100%ers. Get ready to play the same level over, and over, and over again...

Overall, God Mode is flawed, but entertaining for what it tries to be. It feels rushed and has a lot of untapped potential. If you're looking for an arena game where you can just turn off your brain and run-and-gun, then God Mode might pique your interest. However, keep in mind the above mentioned flaws and take them into consideration before deciding if this game is right for you. Overall, I still would give it a positive review, as I did still enjoy playing it. God Mode just didn't live up to what it could of been.

RATING: 5/10

This is a purely splay and flay 3rd person shooter.  It is worth getting if you like 3rd person shooters.

The atmosphere is very hellish (which apparently looks like Ancient Greece).  The graphics are great, though.

In this game there is no time to strategize, hardly time to aim, and you will often get obliterated unless you're playing with some friends who are packing some heavy heat.

The weapons are fun... The monsters are gnarly and neat, although not varied between the different maps.  Unfortunately there are only about 6 maps, which after awhile can get a little old.

In the game description on the store page, I think the RPG/looting elements of this game were over-sold.  There are truly not that many customization options for skins compared to the awesome designs the developers could have come up with.  Also,  no promise of any more additional content coming in the future.  Also, it doesn't take very long to hit the XP/lvl cap and upgrade all your gear, at which point there is no need to loot anything at all because there are no consumables to purchase.  The abilities are universal across the board for players and really don't play into any game tactics at all, nor do they really add much to the characters.

As far as unique gameplay, each map you play has various challenges you must complete to get through the lvl.  There are only about 10-15 different challenges, but they are randomly selected each map which adds a nice layer of difficulty and mixes things up a bit.

reviewText:
Now, overall, after much playing, I can say this, its not for everyone.

The game itself is as it states, a third person run and gun against monsters of the underworld with many weapons, abilities, and customization of your own character. There are many enemies to mow down with all this, a couple or so bosses available, multiplayer with others, and plenty of achivements. And then, comes the cons.

The game is buggy here and there, matchmaking is broken at this point. Lets talk about that for a quickie. Its impossible to find other players either because the game is terrible at it, or there isn't enough players in this meat grinder of a game. Try to find other people, I just dare you to because it is impossible to, so your only hope is single player.

Even though the single player is fun, you'll get bored pretty quick with the repetitiveness of the both the same enemies and 5 levels that it offers in this bundle of a game. Leveling of your weapons and such is slow so get ready to play alot of this game. Its fun in its own right to the likings of the older Serious Sam games out there, but its easy to get bored with, and thats because of the 5 lone levels, thus, removing the fun when you pull a few hours or less into it.

The enemies given in this game are fun and creative, but they show up to offten and the number count on them is relatively small, about an hour or so into the game and you'll start to see them more then you should be. In a run and gun, have a wide variety of enemies like Serious Sam, then it will be a lot better, trust me.

Sound and level design is creative, I actually enjoyed it and wished there was more levels cause the game looks pretty good. Not Guild of Wars or Dark Soul's level of good, but just enough to be enjoyable.

The amount of guns......are desent. Its not big, but its not too small. A couple of them are creative like that buzz saw thing (I forgotten the name), but it will take a while to get to due to the small earnings you get from the single player you MUST play due to, again, the broken multiplayer. And character customization is limited in my opinion overall. There just isn't enough to it that it will keep me or many others attached to.

The game overall? Its an OK game. About a 4.6/10. I give it this due to its lack of content that I was expecting from a run and gun. Run and guns are easy to get repetitive so you need to have plenty of stuff to keep the player interested in. This game only has up to 5 stages and the enemies dont hold it up. Though the design and overall look of the game IS pretty sweet in its own way (lets admit, the only other greek shooter you know of is Will Rock), but it wont have enough to keep others playing. And the broken multiplayer that is shown to be a fun factor that doesn't work doesn't help the game either. This is my speculation overall, and I hope you enjoyed it.

The game isn't for everyone, but if you like shooting stuff, go right ahead, just dont expect the multiplayer to hold up well

reviewText:
God Mode is a pretty straightforward Shoot-em-up, third person style which you can play in single player or in online multiplayer with up to 3 friends. As in similar games such as Painkiller and Serious Sam you fight huge numbers of enemies, advance to the next area, kill all that moves, advance, and so on...

The game adds a bit of variety to that repetitive concept by sometimes giving you random effects for the duration of a battle, such as infinite ammo or tougher enemies. Even though this game is in no way meant to be a revolution to the genre, it has some things that motivate you to play this a few times, like unlockable weapon upgrades, unique activatable abilities, skins and so on, which you can earn by earning experience and collecting coins as you play. The difficulty can be adjusted from anything between baby mode to impossible and can be further refined through several modifiers - the harder the game gets, the more experience you earn.

While the level variety is very small (5 maps), the worlds are well designed. The graphics, effects and animations are very good considering this is just a rather cheap download title, also the game runs smooth at high FPS. The scenarios and the monsters you fight fit the theme of hades, which is ancient greece meets hell, basically. No complaints about the sound, either. The controls are fine, but the movement feels a bit slow overall, which makes strafe-gunning a lot less effective than usual, but you get used to that quickly. Some people have complained about bugs in this game - I have encountered a few glitches with the physics and clipping issues, but those were never gamebreaking, though sometimes hilarious.

Overall, God Mode does its job well, its a nice pickup for any fan of shoot-em-ups, especially when you grab this on sale. It may get repetitive after a while, but if you are joined by a few friends, and have some time to kill (pun intended), this is just the right choice.

reviewText:
Actually pretty well made. Graphics are good, music is ok, no technical problems (except for not being able to bind the left/right arrow - fixed with a little external rebind program but still).

Its basically any games Horde mode, or for those who still remember, UT Rpg Invasion. You progress through a series of arenas by killing everything, collecting ammo, armor and health strewn about. A little twist on the formula is that each arena can have a random beneficial or harmful or neutral effect like infinite ammo or tougher enemies or just everybody wearing a hat. You get xp and gold, you unlock new weapons and their upgrades (damage etc) with higher levels and then purchase them.

The big fat problem is the lasting appeal. Coop makes everything better and again, its  really very well made but i couldnt imagine milking more than a few hours out of this replaying the same five (decently big, granted) maps over and over with increasingly bulletspongy enemies.

Less than two euro for about 3 hours of entertainment so im not complaining, however Serious Sam or Painkiller or heck, Mass Effect 3 MP provides the same with more variation.

reviewText:
This game is OK (the graphics are nice and reasonably well optimized). The main problem with it is that it's not that great if playing single player, and maybe I just picked a bad time of day but after a few minutes I didn't have any luck finding anyone to play coop.

It's basically a relatively mindless arena TPS shoot-em-up game with wacky gameplay modifiers. Decent variety of weapons, and you have to collect ammo for them though that isn't too difficult. Some actions (like reloading and such) take too long for the speed of monsters in the arena (which is why you really need to play coop, so someone can cover you while you're trying to reload). You're pretty much just constantly mobbed with mobs the whole time and in single player you'd need continuous shooting with no reload time to hold them all off.

I didn't really like some of the overly goofy style decisions in the game, like the goofy sarcastic voice, especially since they don't seem to entirely fit with the rest of the style, but I suppose that's just a matter of personal taste. To me these elements are just stupidly goofy, not humorous.

So in short, not a terrible game but I wouldn't recommend buying it unless it's significantly discounted. (I got it in a bundle.) It also pretty much has to be played coop as the design practically requires it even if the implementatin technically doesn't.

reviewText:
if you have some friends to play this game to kill time sure i recommend it. but if you are on your own tough luck. you have no chance to be matched with anyone else due to the fact that almost nobody plays the game.

the lack of variety in maps doesnt help either. with only 6 mazes to chose from you arent looking at much choice. you will find yourself repeating the same steps over and over again making it a pain to level up your character in order to get better weapons.

from what i have seen the difficulty doesnt change anything regarding the behaviour of your enemies as well. their health isnt increased from what i can tell and their intelligence... is the same. they still charge towards you the same in all difficulties. the only difference i have noticed between the difficulties is that the shrines become harder, with more fequent coin drops as the difficulty of the game increases. in bronze difficulty the shrines are pretty standard and most of the time not affecting the gameplay. but as in increases you are faced against more difficult tasks, most of them being constant ammo drain but random ammo drops, armor regeneration but deactivated health pickups, and one hit one kill for both enemies and the player. though they are nice additions and alterations to the game, they get boring rather quickly.

once you get over the drastically draggy and rediculous begining with the very bad weapons provided to you, its weapon upgrading time, which makes the game more fun and easy to progress through the mazes. it takes a while to do so but the reward is satisfying once you can blast multiple enemies with an energy ball shooting gun and shredding the big bosses to pieces with a very powerful minigun!

in a synopsis, this is not a quake arena replacement. not is it better than it. if you see this game on sale, and one or more of your friends can grab it, do so yourself too. its a great game to play with friends, over skype, and sharing a good laugh when enemies stomp you from the back. i do not tink that its worth the 10 dollars, but its definitely a good gift to send to your friend if you see it on sale!

Hello there. Now I usually don't write detailed reviews, but I thought that I needed to get my opinion out there. This game, God Mode has a pretty interesting story. You are a descendant of a god that was banished from the heavens, and now to prove yourself worthy of becoming a god again, you must fight wave after wave of enemies set in a greek mythological world. Let's get into this.
Right off the bat, there's no introduction. It pulls you up to a menu with options to create a match, join one, etc.
I decided to create a match to test whether or not the game was actually fun.
So I spawned in with my SMG and double barrel and walked to where I thought was the destination I had to go to, as the game did not tell me where or how I was supposed to go.
I get to the location and found myself surrounded in a wide open room of skeletons. Classic, I thought.
Shooting and moving being the only thing I knew how to do, I tried to survive. Any control tutorial was non-existent.
After 30 seconds I was dead.
I looked in the controls and found that sprint was space, melee was right click and ADS (aiming down sights) was E, not to mention that the sensitivity for the mouse was extremely high.
As an average PC gamer, I can confirm that those controls are completely ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.
After changing them to my preferred buttons I continued the game, might I remind you that you have 3 lives and while I was changing these settings I was getting slaughtered without consent, listening to my character moan and bleed.
With one life left I managed to kill 10 skeletons and then get brutally ripped apart by a gigantic fat guy.
It wasn't pretty.
I decided to restart the match and change up my tactics a little bit.
All I did was run around the map, firing a clip behind me then collecting ammo/meds and running again.
And then when I had killed everything and was waiting to traverse to the next area, I found myself stuck.
I saw that the problem was that there was skeleton archers atop a bridge far frome my reach. Trying to shoot them proved it to be nearly impossible without wasting every single bullet I had, as the accuracy on the SMG was absolute ****.
After killing them I finally got to move to the next stage, which was pretty much the same thing with a slightly different layout. I died on that stage.
Determined to see what else this game had and to give it another shot I tried multiplayer, and to my surprise I actually found another player. Confused, lost and newby, but I found another player!
We played the same level I was having difficulty on and managed to get to the second to last stage.
During each stage, there is a modifier that changes up gameplay, and the modifier switches upon getting to the next stage. Some are good and some are bad.
During my gameplay with this other player on the second to last level, we got a modifier that was meant to be extremely OP, but in turn was a game breaker.
Every minute or so, one of the players would get a graphically pleasing and high-damage hammer of the gods, that after another minute would switch to the next player.
Both me and him found this hammer extremely under powered, as it hit slow as anything, and only one-hit the weakling skeletons that are usually a 5 shot with your ol' SMG, not to mention that you can't run with this hammer, making fighting harder, bigger, faster foes more difficult. The most difficult to fight was the ranged enemies, as they would run and strafe-fire at you, making fighting them with the hammer completely impossible.
That was the level we died on.

I really think that the devs of this game, in the beginning of development, had everything going for them. A half-fresh game idea, lots of time, etc. But the direction they took it made the game absolutely horrid. To sum everything up, here are some pros and cons:

Pros:
Great graphics
Decent level design
No pay-to-win
Lots of customization

Cons:
Dead matchmaking
Extremely boring farm/grind
Extremely difficult as a beginner
Bland weapons
Bland upgrades
Customization options are all the same with slight differences

I paid a combined $10 for the game both times; if multiplayer was more vibrant than a graveyard, one copy of God Mode could very well be worth the cost of the 4-Pack.

No more than a handful of everything – excepting (slightly dissimilar) customization options, sorts of enemies (not necessarily Types of enemies) and Tests of Faith (randomly generated 'objectives' given as you progress through each stage of the map - these are what make the game good; anything from the distortion of the sound, to the enemies wearing Party Hats, to Weapon Roullette, to brief stints of God Mode (invincibility) and about 40 others) - provided you don’t mind mindlessness, you will find much fun and entertainment to be had.

To be sure, avoiding the throngs of Hades takes a fully focused player – before you’ve acquired several (tens of) thousands of Gold, you won’t even be able to attempt a difficulty higher than Bronze; you’ll be lucky to have half your party survive Silver (should you be playing cooperatively). The mindlessness lies in the 5 maps.
Understand that, with no bias from the PS3, on my pitiful ‘puter, the scenery is AWEsome; quite often I’ll find my completion times are indicative of a poor player. I was busy marveling at the sprawling Basilisk(?) statue, the punishing Tornado (which is really a hurricane in a vertically conical shape) and the… fire dungeon. Honestly, though, you can only play the same 5 maps so many times before it becomes (a little) monotonous. Still: the game is fun and I find it a crime that it didn't get a bigger player-base.

Addressing gameplay: You have your standard weapons (the default SMG should be your go-to gun for a while) and then you’ve a few exotics: Plasma Pistol that shoots in an arc (great for crowd control), Buzzsaw that can both launch blades or be used in melee, Crossbow that shoots (multiple) flaming bolts, etc. Dodging is necessary and you will be appalled at how little it seems to help at times; you might be soothed in knowing that you CAN reload while sprinting. The default Ability, Shield, is decent, but Healing should be the priority (as it has an area-of-effect), and then Salvage for more loot; you can also call down Zeus' bolts or use a Hammer that makes Thor's seem useless.

No grenades, only one map in which native traps could help you, no sniper rifles (per se) or distractions from you as a target: you are on your own, whether actually soloing or not.
There is a gratuitous auto-aim function (you’ll be glad to have it), but the firing rate on the semi-auto weapons detracts from their power, unless you can line up several targets. To reiterate: SWARMS. The auto-aim is handy for the teleporting Mages and the poisonous Scarabs.

All-in-all: A surprisingly fun shooter that I can’t help but call (however loosely or shallowly) God of War with guns. I doubt that the dev’s could have done much better in the execution, with the exceptions of (more) advertising (to ensure at least a decent-sized multiplayer community), more maps and more bosses (with different mechanics to handle each):
The Queen Harpy is the hardest boss because sometimes you’re just screwed, there’s no escaping it's screech. The massive Monsters that are in and stay in the background are just begging to be destroyed; perhaps they could have implemented a sort of platforming/swinging battle to dispense with the fire beast that turns the cogs in the fire dungeon level.
However, I honestly feel that asking for anything more from this title would just be greed on the players’ part. I can understand not wanting to pay full price for such a relatively sparse game with no one still playing it, but if you’re up for an arena game based in Greek mythology, you won't regret going God Mode.

Ever played Painkiller? God Mode is exactly like People Can Fly's first offering, if only in third-person. It's essentially arena combat, which involves facing wave after wave of enemies with little to no context or plot considerations. The object is to outlast this rather gruelling gauntlet, or at least to survive as long as you can.

To help in this, most of the arenas are littered with colour-coded power-ups. Red for health, blue for armour, yellow for ammunition and gold pickups. Green is bad. Stay away from the green stuff, seriously. Most enemies also drop temporary versions of these same items. Being that the game purportedly takes place in Hades, however, and that you're just one of several wayward souls to pass through here (unsuccessfully), each of the stage's distinct arenas confers one of several random buffs or debilitating effects, a bit as if you'd spliced in Unreal Tournament's Mutators and shoved them through a randomizer.

As you can imagine, some buffs will make your life considerably easier (Yay, random applications of actual God Mode!) to markedly worse (you do less damage but your rechargeable ability takes less time to reload?! Dafuq? How is that useful?!). You have no control over which effects are applied and when, which adds to the unpredictability of the basic package. No two games will generate the same items or apply the same stat modifiers, and I'm told the game scales relatively well in multiplayer. The end result is something that plays like a breeze one moment, and that kicks your little heinie to the curb the next. Expect absolutely wild difficulty spikes, considering this – not so much within a single game, but from game to game in general. Considering, your best bet is to learn how to ply your two-weapon loadout as effectively as possible, and to upgrade it as you progress.

Otherwise, God Mode comes with a few customization options in the strictly aesthetic area. You've got a few basic heads, a few basic torsos and thematic variations of each for good measure. This is where the game's very incisive but somewhat superficial sense of humour enters the picture. Wanna play as a cowboy zombie in a camo vest with jeans who also happens to wield a laser pistol? Put in some time, and you'll learn enough gold and levels to unlock extra parts.

Unfortunately, this is pretty much the be-all and end-all of God Mode. You're throwing yourself into nightmarish gladiatorial matches so you can gain more cash so you can customize your loadout so you can throw yourself into yet MORE nightmarish gladiatorial matches without dying... It's a vicious cycle that only seems vicious, because it has one pre-planned way out; that being the levelling up of every single piece of gear in your possession. Once you've unlocked and buffed everything up, then what?

As the game doesn't answer that question, I'll settle with giving it a warm, but cautious endorsement. This is a great quickie for the summer doldrums, folks. Boot up, clear one or two arenas, spend some gold... That's it. No need for serious investment. The guys at Old School obviously know their nineties' FPS gore and splosion-fests.

My advice? Buy this absolutely right away if you're an unconditional Painkiller fan. If you're not and prefer your shooters more slower-paced and tactical, save ten bucks for a rainy day and give it a whirl.

I think God Mode is an original game. I like the concept of riddling creatures from the Greek mythology with bullets. The graphics are decent and although the game only has a few levels some of them look gorgeous.

This is a typical multiplayer shooter: you fight against waves of enemies and the further you progress on the level the tougher encounters you have. Eventually, there is a boss but not every level has a final countdown in this form. You collect XP in order to level up and upon completion of a level you can pick up a lot of gold coins enabling you to purchase upgrades for your weapons and even to customise your character by buying various types of clothing.

God Mode is nothing special but the mythology here makes the shooter an interesting game albeit it still remains a bit mediocre.

I do not recommend it for the same reason I did not recommend the two Sniper Elite Zombie Army games: finding a host is impossible! In fact, even if you are the host you can spend eons until someone joins. And do bear in mind that there is a community willing to play this game even 1 year after its release.

So, if you have friends who are just as eager to play this game as you are do team up with them and unleash your fury on titans, cyclops, skeletons and any other mythical creatures you encounter. Otherwise avoid it if you can.

Review:

God Mode is a Third Person wave based shooter. Most levels consist of just killing all enemies in an area then going through the teleporter to the next. Each area will have a random 'event' occur, for example: Famine: Ammo slowly regens but more ammo spawns to pickup, Armor: Take less damage and rage regens slower, Hats: Enemies have hats, etc. They can be good and bad.

The events run on RNG which can mean on levels like Fortress (which is the only real level that has you progressing and pushing through the enemies rather than just teleporting) a buff like Sanctuary: Enemies take damage near the alter was useless, but that's RNG it differs up each playthrough.

There is a level system and gold system, Unless you are playing solo or have an upgraded SMG or other good damage dealing weapon you won't get much experience per run really. All that experience and levelling does is keep you locked away from the higher level weapons and upgrades.

Gold is fairly slow to be made overall at least to begin with, a run on bronze would net about 20k gold, where base upgrades cost 10k, then 20k. Weapons range from 10k+, apparel 5k+.

The matchmaking is pretty horrendous which doesn't help when there is an extremely low amount of players as it is.

It's a fun game to play with a couple friends, I never got too much into it but the 4 hours I played it were pretty enjoyable.

As a general, I really like horde mode/wave type games which is why I bought God Mode. However, after a few games in I was pretty shocked at how I was not enjoying it at all. Not even slightly.

At first glance, it has potential. Waves of enemies with different stages and modifiers that are constantly changing. Giving you a pretty good 3rd person shooter challenge. You can 'customise' your characters look and change their 2 guns. You level up and get money during games to buy these upgrades with.

God Mode fails in the areas which seem like they should be positives. The Gameplay is extremely repetetive. What would you expect from a wave mode game? Well I expected something. The enemies just seem to run at you from start to finish so it just becomes a game of running in a circle shooting behind you. There is a sprint and a roll but both of those get you nowhere fast so they're pointless to use.
The 'customisable' character is actually not very customisable. There are about 5 options. and then there are variations of those options. So you'll have a zombie or a clown and then after the next level you'll unlock a pirate zombie and a pirate clown. All thats been added is a pretty unimaginitve hat.

Lastly, the levelling is the longest grind Iv'e ever seen for a game with such limited gameplay. With an mmo you would expect a long grind because there are so many things to do, with a game that has 5 stages which are all offer the same wave mode gameplay, you would think the grind would be a bit more forgiving.... It's not.

GOD MODE - 3 / 10
